name: phosphorane, pentachloro-
Reason: The basic unit for phosphorane, phosphine (PH3), has a melting point of -133.5°C. The chloro substituents are highly electronegative and bulky, which provides increased intermolecular forces (Van der Waals and dipole-dipole interactions) compared to hydrogen. Each chloro substituent raises the melting point significantly. Here, there are five chloro substituents, which also significantly increase the molecular weight. Assuming each chloro substituent adds approximately +36.3°C to the melting point (the approximate difference in melting points between PH3 and PCl3, considering PCl3 has a melting point of -93.6°C and has three chloros more than PH3), the total increase from the five chloros would be +181.5°C.

name: phosphorane, pentachloro-
Reason: The basic unit for phosphorane, phosphine (PH3), has a melting point of -133.5°C. Each chloro substituent on the phosphorus atom not only increases the molecular weight but also greatly enhances the intermolecular forces due to their high electronegativity and the polar nature of the P-Cl bonds, resulting in significantly stronger dipole-dipole interactions and potential for Van der Waals forces. Typically, one chloro substituent can be estimated to raise the melting point by at least 36.3°C based on the increase in melting point from phosphine to phosphorus trichloride (PCl3) which has three chloro substituents. With five chloro substituents in pentachlorophosphorane, the cumulative effect will have a more pronounced increase. It is reasonable to consider that the effect of adding successive chloro groups may not be purely additive due to potential steric hindrance and other structural factors. Adjusting for this, an estimate of a +28°C increase per chloro substituent could be given, leading to a total estimated increase of +140°C.

name: phosphorane, pentachloro-
Reason: The basic unit for the compound pentachlorophosphorane is phosphane (PH3), which has a melting point of -133.5 degrees Celsius. Each chlorine (Cl) atom adds significant molecular weight and increases van der Waals forces due to its larger electron cloud compared to a hydrogen atom. Chlorine is highly electronegative and adds polarity to the molecule, further increasing intermolecular attractions. Thus, the melting point is expected to rise with each additional chlorine atom. Estimating the effect of each chlorine atom to be around +36.3 degrees Celsius (given the total increase must account for the change from -133.5 to 148 degrees Celsius over 5 chlorines), we can calculate the predicted melting point.
